evidence.evidence_text: 773 burial mounds from TRAP 2009-2011 survey, Kazanlak Valley (85 sq km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In this study we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria... This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km
the model reported good learning and model fit (F1 5 0.87)

evidence.evidence_text: First model: 12.8% true positive rate (19/148), 87.1% false positive rate
evidence.verbatim_quote: only 19 out of 148 tiles (12.8%) tagged by the model with at least a 60% chance of having a mound actually contained one... 129 of the tagged tiles (87.1%) were false positives

evidence.evidence_text: First model: 4.9% detection rate (38/773), 95.3% false negative rate
evidence.verbatim_quote: The 19 true-positive tiles contained 38 mounds... out of 773 in the study area (4.9%)... a false negative rate of 95.3%
The second model's performance declined to an F1 score of 0.62

evidence.evidence_text: Second model: 2.7% detection rate (21/773), 94.8% false positive rate (273/288)
evidence.verbatim_quote: only 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%) were detected... The remaining 273 of 288 tiles were false positives (94.8%)
Developing our CNN model required approximately 135 person-hours from conceptualisation and experiments to validation and documentation
ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data... The model was deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python
In the 2021 run... we used all 773 cutouts... In the 2022 run, we selected 249 cutouts where a mound was discernible

evidence.evidence_text: Literature: 63% (44/70) fail to mention negative aspects
evidence.verbatim_quote: 44 abstracts (63%) fail to mention any negative aspects of AI/ML approaches at all

evidence.evidence_text: Three GitHub repositories with complete code
evidence.verbatim_quote: scripts are available in public repositories: (1) https://github.com/adivea/cnn-testing (2) https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/burial-mounds (3) https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/MoundDetection
two IKONOS scenes covering 600 sq km... panchromatic band at 1 m resolution and a multispectral image... at 4 m resolution

evidence.evidence_text: ML publications: 17% of archaeological remote sensing in 2023
evidence.verbatim_quote: These 21 publications represent about 17% of the 2023 total (n=125) for archaeological remote sensing
The ratio of positive to negative training data was approximately 1:2 (32%–68%)

claims.claim_text: Study tests CNN transfer learning for mound detection against 773 field-verified ground truth
claims.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery

claims.claim_text: External field validation is essential for CNN archaeological prospection
claims.verbatim_quote: making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.claim_text: First model failed: F1=0.87 but only 4.9% actual detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features

claims.claim_text: Self-reported ML metrics are misleadingly high vs actual performance
claims.verbatim_quote: self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.claim_text: Second model (curated) performed worse: F1=0.62, 2.7% detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds... performed worse

claims.claim_text: Training data curation worsened rather than improved results
claims.verbatim_quote: despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful

claims.claim_text: Manual approaches likely more efficient given 135h investment and poor results
claims.verbatim_quote: manual approaches like visual inspection by experts or crowdsourcing to volunteers would probably be more efficient

claims.claim_text: ML-archaeology literature shows publication bias toward positive results
claims.verbatim_quote: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias

claims.claim_text: Code transparency achieved via three public repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: scripts are available in public repositories

claims.claim_text: AI/ML nearing mainstream adoption in archaeological remote sensing
claims.verbatim_quote: AI/ML is on the cusp of 'crossing the chasm'

claims.claim_text: CNN detected background features (edges, roads) rather than mounds
claims.verbatim_quote: the model seemed to select bright lines and edges (forest, roads), rather than round shapes more likely to represent mounds

claims.claim_text: Paper provides cautionary counterbalance for ML adopters
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the failure of a good-faith attempt to utilise these approaches as a counterbalance and cautionary tale

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNNs fail for varied features in heterogeneous landscapes with low-touch training
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features... within a heterogeneous landscape

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Field validation reveals ML performance failures hidden by self-reported metrics
trigger_text: self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Gap between F1 (0.87/0.62) and detection (4.9%/2.7%) demonstrates field validation reveals failures standard metrics miss.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Transfer learning assumptions may fail for archaeological heterogeneous targets
trigger_text: Transfer learning assumes that large, complex models can be pre-trained... then fine-tuned
even an advanced pre-trained model... is likely to fail when asked to detect somewhat variable features against very heterogeneous backgrounds
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Results challenge transfer learning assumption that pre-trained models generalise to complex archaeological domains.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Publication bias distorts expectations for new ML practitioners
trigger_text: The overwhelmingly positive tone of these papers likely indicates... 'publication bias'
Early-majority adopters may find ML difficult to implement
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Biased literature creates expectations gap for practitioners entering field.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Resource transparency enables informed adoption decisions
trigger_text: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Rare resource reporting implies this information necessary for decision-making.

research_designs.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds... We developed a pre-trained CNN
We first used an indiscriminate collection... We next used only those mounds that we deemed easily discernible

research_designs.design_text: External validation with independent ground truth
research_designs.verbatim_quote: we applied the models to our imagery and validated results using our field data

protocols.protocol_text: GPS, height, diameter, land use recording
Web of Science search with manual review
